Choice 2: 2 hours of Risk Management and 6 hours of AREC-approved electives
Choice 3: 1 Risk Management course and 10 AREC-approved elective courses
Choice 4: 3 hours of Risk Management and 12 hours of AREC-approved core real estate courses
Explanation: Alabama continuing education course work consists of 3 hours of Risk Management and 9 hours of AREC-approved electives

Question: What may be substituted for the Alabama continuing education requirements?
Choice 1: 15 hours of continuing education course work completed in another state
Choice 2: Excess continuing education hours completed in the prior license period
Choice 3: State Legislature service during the license period
Choice 4: Community service hours equal to the number of required continuing education hours
Explanation: State Legislature service may be substituted for the Alabama continuing education requirements. Licensees on inactive status and licensees who turn 65 years old on or before September 30, 2000, and have been licensed for 10 years prior to that are also exempt

Question: What is a reciprocal license?
Choice 1: A license issued in one state in exchange for a license issued in another state
Choice 2: A license issued as a result of a co-broker agreement
Choice 3: An Alabama license issued to an individual who holds a license in another state
Choice 4: An Alabama salesperson license issued when the licensee transfers to a new qualifying broker
Explanation: A reciprocal license is an Alabama license issued to an individual who holds a license in another state

Question: An applicant for a reciprocal license must
Choice 1: complete 6 hours of Alabama course work and pass a written examination on national and Alabama state real estate
Choice 2: complete 15 hours of Alabama course work and pass a written examination on national and Alabama state real estate
Choice 3: complete 6 hours of Alabama course work and pass a written examination on Alabama real estate
Choice 4: complete 60 hours of Alabama course work and pass a written examination on national and Alabama state real estate
Explanation: An applicant for a reciprocal license must complete 6 hours of Alabama course work and pass a written examination on Alabama real estate

Question: Both Alabama licensees and reciprocal licensees must complete
Choice 1: 15 hours of AREC-approved continuing education course work every 2 years
Choice 2: 6 hours of AREC-approved continuing education course work every 2 years
Choice 3: 30 hours of post-license course work every 2 years
Choice 4: 9 hours of Risk Management course work every year
Explanation: Both Alabama licensees and reciprocal licensees must complete 15 hours of AREC-approved continuing education course work every 2 years

Question: Which of the following is required in a co-broker agreement between an out-of-state principal broker and an Alabama qualifying broker?
Choice 1: The Alabama qualifying broker must approve all advertisements created by the nonresident broker
Choice 2: The Alabama qualifying broker must allow the out-of-state licensee to deposit funds in a bank located solely in the out-of-state licensee’s home state
Choice 3: The Alabama qualifying broker must supervise all property showings the nonresident broker performs
Choice 4: The an out-of-state principal broker must provide AREC with proof of his or her out-of-state license
Explanation: If there is a co-broker agreement between a nonresident broker and an Alabama broker, the Alabama broker must supervise all property showings the nonresident broker performs

Question: A  copy of the co-broker agreement must be filed with AREC within ________ of execution
Choice 1: 5 business days
Choice 2: 10 days
Choice 3: 30 days
Choice 4: 1 year
Explanation: A copy of the co-broker agreement must be filed with AREC within 10 days of execution

Question: When must an inactive licensee complete continuing education requirements?
Choice 1: Within 1 year of reactivating the license
Choice 2: Every license period
Choice 3: Prior to reactivating the license
Choice 4: Never
Explanation: An inactive licensee must complete the continuing education requirements prior to reactivating the license

Question: Applicants for an Alabama real estate broker license must
Choice 1: be at least 21 years old
Choice 2: be a U.S. citizen
Choice 3: be an Alabama resident
Choice 4: be a high school graduate or the equivalent
Explanation: Applicants for an Alabama real estate broker license must be a high school graduate or the equivalent, at least 19 years old, a U.S. citizen or permanent resident alien, and a resident of any U.S. state

Question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?
Choice 1: The AREC requires both state and national criminal history checks on any licensure applicant
Choice 2: The AREC is responsible for the cost of the criminal history check on any licensure applicant
Choice 3: The applicant for broker licensure must submit fingerprints to the appropriate agency
Choice 4: The applicant may be denied licensure based on the findings of a criminal history check
Explanation: The applicant is responsible for the cost of the criminal history check which must be current to the date of license issuance

Question: Which of the following statements is TRUE?
Choice 1: An applicant for broker licensure must complete a 90-hour pre-license real estate course
Choice 2: A broker applicant must have been licensed as a real estate salesperson in Alabama for at least 24 of the preceding 36 months
Choice 3: An applicant for broker licensure must have been licensed in any state for at least 36 months prior to applying for licensure in Alabama
Choice 4: Proof of prior salesperson licensure must be submitted to the AREC along with the broker license application
Explanation: Proof of prior salesperson licensure must be submitted to the AREC along with the broker license application

Question: Which of the following statements is TRUE?
Choice 1: An applicant for broker licensure must pass only the state licensure examination with a score of 70%.
Choice 2: A broker applicant must pass the licensure examination within 6 months of pre-license course completion
Choice 3: Once meeting all other requirements, a broker applicant has 12 months in which to take and pass the licensure examination
Choice 4: There is no fee associated with taking the licensure examination
Explanation: A broker applicant must pass the licensure examination within 6 months of pre-license course completion

Question: Who is responsible for the actions of salespersons and brokers at a company's branch office?
Choice 1: The main company qualifying broker
Choice 2: The branch office qualifying broker
Choice 3: The supervising qualifying broker
Choice 4: Both the main company qualifying broker and the branch office qualifying broker
Explanation: The main company qualifying broker and the branch office qualifying broker are responsible for the actions of salespersons and brokers at a company’s branch office

Question: Qualifying Broker Quinn is not interested in having his company represent buyers. Brokers Bill and Bob, who work for Quinn, want to represent property buyers. Under Alabama law, what must Bill and Bob do to represent buyers?
Choice 1: Transfer their licenses to another qualifying broker who represents buyers
Choice 2: Stay with Quinn and represent buyers outside of their working hours with Quinn
Choice 3: Tell Quinn they do not agree with his decision and represent buyers anyway
Choice 4: Report Quinn to the AREC for limiting his business services
Explanation: Every activity a licensee performs must be performed in the name of the licensed company and under the qualifying broker. Therefore, Bill and Bob cannot represent buyers unless Broker Quinn agrees to it. Thus, they have to transfer their licenses to another qualifying broker who represents buyers

Question: Which of the following is NOT an intended consequence of Alabama law?
Choice 1: The qualifying broker is responsible for the actions of brokers under his or her supervision
Choice 2: The qualifying broker and his or her associates have  an employer-employee relationship
Choice 3: The qualifying broker is liable for any damage caused by his or her associate brokers who violate license law
Choice 4: The qualifying broker is responsible for assuring that all transactions performed by his or her licensees comply with AREC rules
Explanation: Even though the law requires the qualifying broker to supervise the associate brokers and salespersons licensed under him or her, the law is not meant to establish an employer-employee relationship. The broker and licensee may establish such a relationship, but the law does not automatically establish it for them

Question: A  qualifying broker may serve more than one company if
Choice 1: the AREC gives written consent
Choice 2: the qualifying broker's license is registered under all the companies
Choice 3: he or she obtains written consent from all of the companies
Choice 4: the qualifying broker will be conducting business from all of the separate company locations
Explanation: A qualified broker may serve more than one company if he or she obtains written consent from all of the companies

Question: Which of the following is FALSE regarding temporary qualifying brokers?
Choice 1: A temporary qualifying broker is designated for a new company until the permanent qualifying broker obtains the appropriate license
Choice 2: The temporary qualifying broker must be a broker or have been a licensed salesperson for 1 year prior to designation as the temporary qualifying broker
Choice 3: The temporary qualifying broker can only serve as such for 6 months
Choice 4: The company license will become inactive if a qualifying broker is not designated within the required time frame
Explanation: A temporary qualifying broker is typically appointed if a company’s qualifying broker dies or becomes disabled. A company is allowed to operate under the temporary qualifying broker for no more than 6 months. A temporary qualifying broker must have been licensed for at least 1 year prior to the application being submitted

Question: When a salesperson receives earnest money from a client for the purchase of a property, what must the salesperson do with the money?
Choice 1: Immediately deposit the money into an escrow account
Choice 2: Open a new trust account to hold the funds separate from other funds
Choice 3: Deposit the money into the real estate company's business account for safe keeping
Choice 4: Submit the money to his or her qualifying broker
Explanation: A salesperson must submit to his or her qualifying broker all the funds that come into the salesperson’s possession, including earnest money for the purchase of a property

Question: If a purchase contract involves more than one qualifying broker, who should deposit related funds into an escrow account?
Choice 1: The seller's qualifying broker
Choice 2: The buyer's qualifying broker
Choice 3: The client's attorney
Choice 4: Any of the involved qualifying brokers
Explanation: If a purchase contract involves more than one qualifying broker, any of the involved qualifying brokers can deposit related funds into an escrow account

Question: When are trust funds to be disbursed?
Choice 1: As needed
Choice 2: At closing
Choice 3: Within 7 days of closing
Choice 4: On a date agreed upon by all involved parties
Explanation: Trust funds should be disbursed within 7 days of closing

Question: Under Alabama law, qualifying brokers may
Choice 1: deposit all funds belonging to others into his or her business account
Choice 2: commingle trust funds
Choice 3: use trust funds as necessary for the qualifying broker's personal use
Choice 4: hold trust funds belonging to multiple clients in the same trust account
Explanation: Under Alabama law, qualifying brokers may hold trust funds belonging to multiple clients in the same trust account

Question: Which of the following will NOT occur if a licensee violates provisions of Alabama law pertaining to trust funds?
Choice 1: The licensee may have his or her license revoked
Choice 2: The licensee may have a $7,000 fine imposed for each violation
Choice 3: The licensee may have his or her license suspended and have a fine imposed
Choice 4: The licensee may be reprimanded
Explanation: If a licensee violates provisions of Alabama law pertaining to trust funds, the Commission can impose a fine of at least $100 but not more than $2,500, suspend or revoke the licensee’s license, reprimand the license, or suspend or revoke the licensee and impose a fine

Question: Under Alabama law, what is the time frame for reconciling trust fund accounts?
Choice 1: Monthly
Choice 2: Within 5 days of receiving the bank statement
Choice 3: Annually
Choice 4: There is no time frame designated under Alabama law
Explanation: Under Alabama law, there is no time frame for reconciling trust fund accounts

Question: When must a licensee provide an estimated closing statement to a potential buyer?
Choice 1: When the purchase offer becomes a contract
Choice 2: When the buyer signs the purchase offer
Choice 3: When the seller signs the purchase offer
Choice 4: 5 days prior to closing
Explanation: A licensee must provide an estimated closing statement to a potential buyer when the buyer signs the purchase offer

Question: Which of the following would be considered credits for the buyer?
Choice 1: Title insurance, property inspections, escrow fees
Choice 2: Commissions, excise taxes, title clearing
Choice 3: Earnest money deposits, down payment, adjustments for attorney fee overpayment
Choice 4: Prepaid property insurance, prepaid utilities, prepaid property taxes
Explanation: Earnest money deposits, down payment, and adjustments for attorney fee overpayment are considered credits to the buyer

Question: Failure to disclose estimated closing costs is a violation of
Choice 1: Fair Credit Act
Choice 2: RESPA
Choice 3: IRS reporting regulations
Choice 4: Federal Mortgage Fair Financing Act
Explanation: Failure to disclose estimated closing costs is a violation of RESPA

Question: Homeowner Joe wants to advertise his vacation home for rent. If Joe advertises the home himself instead of obtaining a licensed real estate broker to advertise the home, what Alabama law will Joe be violating?
Choice 1: Article 1 of Chapter 27 of Alabama License Law
Choice 2: Article 2 of Chapter 27 of Alabama License Law
Choice 3: AREC Rules
Choice 4: None
Explanation: Alabama license law exempts property owners from licensing requirements when the owners are managing their own property or engaging in a real estate transaction involving their own property. A property owner can manage, lease, or sell his or her own property without needing to be licensed as a real estate salesperson or broker

Question: Licensee Lou wants to advertise his own home for sale and will disclose his licensee status. If Lou advertises the home himself instead of obtaining another licensed real estate broker to advertise the home, what Alabama law will Joe be violating?
Choice 1: Article 1 of Chapter 27 of Alabama License Law
Choice 2: Article 2 of Chapter 27 of Alabama License Law
Choice 3: AREC Rules
Choice 4: None
Explanation: Alabama license law exempts property owners from licensing requirements when the owners are managing their own property or engaging in a real estate transaction involving their own property. A property owner can manage, lease, or sell his or her own property without needing to be licensed as a real estate salesperson or broker

Question: Broker Blake is handling the sale of a home and wants to place for sale signs on the street corner near the home. To whom will Blake need to pay a fee for placing the sign on the street corner?
Choice 1: The local city or town government
Choice 2: The Department of Transportation
Choice 3: The local county government
Choice 4: No one
Explanation: Real estate licensees have the legal right to advertise property for sale, lease, or transfer using signs that are affixed to or located on the property itself. Alabama does not allow a municipal corporation or local government to impose a fee or tax on the signs, whether the signs are located on or near the property

Question: Which closing statement(s) is the broker required to retain?
Choice 1: His or her client's signed statement
Choice 2: Both the buyer's and the seller's signed statements
Choice 3: The statement signed by both the seller and the buyer
Choice 4: None
Explanation: A broker is required to retain his or her client’s signed statement

Question: If Broker Buford is representing Seller Sam in the sale of Sam's property and Buford would like to purchase the property himself, what must he disclose to Sam to avoid violation of Alabama law?
Choice 1: He must disclose that he is a licensed real estate broker
Choice 2: He must disclose how he will finance the mortgage
Choice 3: He must disclose that he is the intended buyer
Choice 4: He must disclose that the seller should obtain a different broker for the transaction
Explanation: If the licensee is seeking to purchase an interest in a property being sold by his or her brokerage company, the licensee must disclose his or her intention to the property seller or the seller's agent. The licensee must inform the seller that he or she is a licensed real estate salesperson or broker and that he or she is the intended buyer of the property

Question: Which of the following advertisements would comply with Alabama law?
Choice 1: 4-bedroom home on beautiful lake, $400,000 or best offer, contact Real Estate Broker Joseph Smith for information. (The home has 4 bedrooms, is across the street from a lake, and the seller's $400,000 price is firm.)
Choice 2: Stunning 3-bedroom townhouse in prime downtown area, reasonable homeowner association fees, contact 800-555-5555 for more information. (The townhouse has 2 bedrooms and a bonus area with no closet and is located in an area with high crime rates.)
Choice 3: Reasonably priced 2-bedroom, 2-bath home in quiet neighborhood near schools and shopping, contact Joseph Smith, a licensed Real Estate Broker, at 800-555-5555 for details. (The house has 2 bedrooms and 2 baths and is located in a quiet neighborhood near a small park, 2 schools, and a small shopping center.)
Choice 4: Call Joe Smith for information on this beauty – 5 bedrooms, 3 baths, in-ground swimming pool, attached garage, located in quiet neighborhood. (The house has an above-the-ground pool, a garage that has been converted to the 5th bedroom, and is located across the street from a busy dog park.)
Explanation: When advertising real estate, licensees must be honest. They are prohibited from making false promises that could potentially influence, persuade, or induce a consumer to enter into a contract. They are also prohibited from flagrant misrepresentation in any form of advertising. Publishing any advertisement that deceives the public or is likely to deceive the public is against the law

Question: A  mortgage loan origination fee would be a
Choice 1: credit to the seller
Choice 2: credit to the buyer
Choice 3: debit to the seller
Choice 4: debit to the buyer
Explanation: A mortgage loan origination fee would be a debit to the buyer

Question: Prorated prepaid property taxes would be a
Choice 1: debit to the seller
Choice 2: credit to the buyer and the seller
Choice 3: debit to the buyer and credit to the seller
Choice 4: debit to the buyer and the seller
Explanation: Prorated prepaid property taxes would be a debit to the buyer and credit to the seller

Question: An agent who has a written agency agreement to represent both the buyer and the seller in the same real estate transaction is a
Choice 1: single agent
Choice 2: sub-agent
Choice 3: dual agent
Choice 4: transaction facilitator
Explanation: A limited consensual dual agent is an agent who has a written agency agreement to represent both the buyer and the seller in the same real estate transaction

Question: An individual who is provided brokerage services by a broker with no agency agreement is a
Choice 1: customer
Choice 2: seller
Choice 3: client
Choice 4: buyer
Explanation: An individual who is provided brokerage services by a broker with no agency agreement is a customer

Question: If a consumer refuses to sign the Brokerage Services Disclosure form, the licensee should
Choice 1: forego use of the form
Choice 2: sign the form for the consumer
Choice 3: refuse to work with that consumer
Choice 4: note the refusal on the form
Explanation: If a consumer refuses to sign the Brokerage Services Disclosure form, the licensee should note the refusal on the form

Question: What written document is required to be provided to consumers before brokerage services are provided?
Choice 1: Consumer Agreement form
Choice 2: Real Estate Brokerage Services Disclosure form
Choice 3: Consumer Information Booklet
Choice 4: Alabama Brokerage Overview Booklet
Explanation: The AREC wrote a Consumer Information Booklet to tell consumers what they need to know when working with a real estate licensee

Question: If a licensee is representing both the buyer and the seller in a transaction and the two parties each want a different selling price for the property, what should the licensee do?
Choice 1: Determine fair market value for the property and require both parties use that price
Choice 2: Allow the seller to set the price and advise the buyer to pay the seller's price
Choice 3: Advise the seller if he wants to sell the property, he should accept the buyer's price offer
Choice 4: Advise both parties equally and help them negotiate a price that is fair for both of them
Explanation: If the licensee is representing both the buyer and the seller, he or she must strive to represent both equally and fairly, avoiding conflict whenever and wherever possible

Question: What must be disclosed under RECAD?
Choice 1: The licensing hierarchy at the real estate company
Choice 2: The duties of the broker to the client
Choice 3: The available brokerage services
Choice 4: The broker's skills and experience
Explanation: RECAD requires brokers to disclose a non-agency relationship and the available brokerage services to a consumer as soon as reasonably possible

Question: What is the main difference between a customer and a client?
Choice 1: The customer does not pay for services, but the client does
Choice 2: The licensee has obligations only to the client and not to the customer
Choice 3: The licensee must provide an agency disclosure form to a client but not to a customer
Choice 4: The client has signed an agency agreement, but the customer has not
Explanation: The main difference between a customer and client is that a client has signed an agency agreement, but the customer has not

Question: In which brokerage arrangement does the licensee work with both the seller and the buyer with no signed agency agreement?
Choice 1: Transaction facilitator
Choice 2: Single agency
Choice 3: Subagency
Choice 4: Dual agency
Explanation: In a transaction brokerage arrangement, the licensee works with both the seller and the buyer with no signed agency agreement

Question: In which brokerage arrangement does the agent represent both the buyer and seller in a transaction with both parties’ written consent?
Choice 1: Transaction facilitator
Choice 2: Single agency
Choice 3: Subagency
Choice 4: Dual agency
Explanation: In the subagency arrangement, the agent represents one client and performs duties to assist the primary agent

Question: In what way does Alabama mandate consumers' rights?
Choice 1: By requiring a signed agency agreement before the broker can work with the consumer
Choice 2: By not allowing a broker to represent more than one party in the same transaction
Choice 3: By requiring a minimum level of services
Choice 4: By use of the Commission Disclosure Booklet
Explanation: Alabama law requires a minimum level of services and obligations on all real estate licensees to all consumers regardless of their relationship

Question: When a licensee represents more than one client in the same transaction, to whom does the licensee owe fiduciary duties?
Choice 1: Only to the seller of the property
Choice 2: Only to the buyer of the property
Choice 3: Only to the qualifying broker for whom the licensee works
Choice 4: To all clients the licensee represents
Explanation: When the licensee represents more than one client in the same transaction, he or she owes the same duties to all those represented clients, unless the duties to one client would violate the duties to other clients

Question: Which of the following duties does a licensee owe to a customer?
Choice 1: To put the customer's best interests ahead of any other party to the transaction
Choice 2: To disclose to the customer any known information that is material to the transaction
Choice 3: To answer questions related to the transaction completely and accurately
Choice 4: To fulfill all obligations required by the agency agreement
Explanation: A licensee must answer all customer questions related to the transaction completely and accurately

Question: Which of the following is NOT a penalty for violating any of the Alabama License Laws or AREC Administrative Rules?
Choice 1: License suspension
Choice 2: Fines
Choice 3: Criminal charges
Choice 4: Community service
Explanation: Community service is not a penalty for violating any of the Alabama License Laws or AREC Administrative Rules

Question: If the AREC receives a complaint about a licensee allegedly violating a license law, which of the following will the Commission do first?
Choice 1: Suspend the licensee's license
Choice 2: Reprimand the licensee
Choice 3: Schedule a hearing about the complaint
Choice 4: Begin an investigation into the complaint
Explanation: If the AREC receives a complaint about a licensee allegedly violating a license law, the Commission will begin with an investigation into the complaint

Question: When an individual does not admit guilt to a crime but accepts the punishment anyway, this is called
Choice 1: a guilty plea
Choice 2: a plea of nolo contendere
Choice 3: a plea of no responsibility
Choice 4: a plea accepting responsibility
Explanation: A plea of nolo contendere is when an individual does not admit guilt to a crime but accepts the punishment anyways

Question: Which of the following acts would represent fulfillment of an agent’s obligations to a client under the license law?
Choice 1: The licensee shares confidential information with another party to the transaction
Choice 2: The licensee does not disclose the agency relationship to the client at first interaction
Choice 3: The licensee discloses the property's structural defects to a potential buyer
Choice 4: The licensee does not present an offer to the seller that is way below the seller's asking price
Explanation: A licensee is required to make all required disclosures

Question: If an individual files a lawsuit against a broker for misrepresentation, what must the broker do?
Choice 1: Resign from the company where he or she is employed
Choice 2: Notify the complainant's attorney that he or she did not misrepresent
Choice 3: Notify the AREC of the suit
Choice 4: Turn his or her license over to the AREC within 10 days after receiving notice of the action
Explanation: If an individual files a lawsuit against a broker for misrepresentation, the broker must notify the AREC within 10 days of receiving notice of the lawsuit

Question: Which of the following qualities is foremost when applying for a real estate license and practicing real estate?
Choice 1: Skill
Choice 2: Experience
Choice 3: Education
Choice 4: Honesty
Explanation: Under Alabama license law, the first obligation that licensees have to all consumers is to provide services honestly and in good faith

Question: Obtaining a real estate license by fraud is what type of violation issue?
Choice 1: Honesty and good faith issue
Choice 2: Accountability issue
Choice 3: Reporting issue
Choice 4: Representation issue
Explanation: Obtaining a real estate license by fraud is violating the requirement of honesty and good faith

Question: Jeremy is representing a client who is selling his property. Jeremy has found a buyer for the property, but he knows the buyer won't qualify for the mortgage loan. So, Jeremy gives the buyer $10,000 that Jeremy knows he'll get  back in his commission. All the buyer has to do is agree to purchase this particular home and not tell anyone about the money. Has Jeremy broken a law, and if so, which one?
Choice 1: No, Jeremy has not broken any laws because he's simply helping out the buyer
Choice 2: No, Jeremy has not broken any laws because no one will know about the money
Choice 3: Yes, Jeremy has broken the law that says brokers must disclose confidential information to the client
Choice 4: Yes, Jeremy has broken the law that says rebates and incentives must be disclosed
Explanation: Giving any rebate or incentive legally depends mostly on how and when it is given. In Alabama, the incentive must be given before or at closing and must be disclosed to all parties involved in the transaction, to include the seller, buyer, and lender or guaranteeing agency (FHA, VA, HUD). A rebate or other incentive that is given after or outside of the closing and is related to the transaction violates the law. Since rebates given before or during closing must be disclosed, an undisclosed rebate related to the transaction also violates the law

Question: If Sandra is selling a home that sustained structural damage from an earthquake, what allows her to avoid disclosing that damage to a potential buyer?
Choice 1: Caveat emptor
Choice 2: Keeping her client's confidential information confidential
Choice 3: The insignificance of the damage
Choice 4: Nothing, she is required to disclose the damage
Explanation: Alabama license law states that licensees must not make a material misrepresentation or fail to disclose any latent structural defect or other defect to the potential buyer. The licensee must know about the defect(s), and the defects must not be trivial or insignificant. The defects must qualify as significant factors in the buyer deciding whether or not to purchase or lease the property

Question: Charlie is advertising a home for sale. The home has 2 bedrooms, 1 bathroom, an unattached garage which the current owner is using as a bonus room, a do-it-yourself kitchen remodel that was never finished, and the home is located next to an empty lot. Which of the following advertisements for this home would be legal?
Choice 1: Beautiful 3 bed, 1 bath home with bonus room and newly remodeled kitchen. Call Charlie Juniper at 555-3939
Choice 2: 3 bed, 1 bath fixer upper with detached garage. Located next to public park. Call Charlie Juniper at 555-3939
Choice 3: Partially remodeled home with 3 bed, 1 bath, and detached garage. Call Charlie Juniper, a licensed real estate broker, at 555-3939. Best Buy Realtors
Choice 4: Nice home that still needs some work. Partially remodeled kitchen, 3 bed, 1 bath, bonus room. Located next to empty lot. Call Best Buy Realtors at 555-3939 and ask for Charlie.
Explanation: Licensees must not publish or cause to be published any advertisement that deceives the public, even if it is only likely to deceive. Advertisements must not create a misleading impression

Question: Jasper is Peggy's agent. Peggy and a buyer have signed a purchase agreement for Peggy's house. Although the transaction has not actually closed yet, they do have a contract in place. Jasper recently overheard the buyer saying he would have paid a lot more for the house if he'd had to. Jasper knows a higher selling price would mean a higher commission for him. What should Jasper do?
Choice 1: Tell Peggy right away and see if she wants to go forward with the transaction
Choice 2: Encourage Peggy to breach the contract and renegotiate the selling price
Choice 3: Tell Peggy not to pay for any needed repairs to the house because the buyer apparently has plenty of money to pay for them himself
Choice 4: Jasper should do nothing because the contract is already signed
Explanation: The licensee must not convince either party to break the contract and substitute a new one that will benefit the licensee more than the original contract

Question: Which of the following statements about the license law is TRUE?

Choice 3: No license is required to negotiate rent for a landlord
Choice 4: Any demonstration of untrustworthiness on the part of a licensee is a violation of the law
Explanation: Honesty and trustworthiness are required to be an Alabama real estate licensee, so proof of the contrary is a license law violation.

Question: If a licensee does not disclose the true terms of a real estate sale to a lender, the licensee is violating the mandate to make that disclosure. What other mandate is the licensee violating?
Choice 1: No deceitful advertising

Question: Which of the following would violate the mandate for handling trust funds?

Choice 2: Depositing the funds in a trust account with funds belonging to other clients

Choice 4: Depositing the funds in the company's business account in a federally insured bank in Alabama
Explanation: Alabama license law requires licensees to have any money belonging to others deposited into a separate federally insured account in a financial institution located in Alabama

Question: Which of the following statements is true about commingling?

Choice 2: Commingling is having funds received by different licensees deposited in the same trust account
Choice 3: Commingling is mixing a client's funds with the licensee's personal funds
Choice 4: When the licensee turns the client's funds over to the qualifying broker, the funds become commingled
Explanation: Commingling, or mixing others' money with the licensee's personal or business funds is not allowed

Question: If records related to real estate transactions are not kept for at least _________, a violation has occurred

Question: Francis, a licensed salesperson, has listed Mary’s house for sale. While preparing the listing sheet, he estimates the room dimensions by eye but is off by quite a bit and also forgets to include one of the bedrooms. In inspecting the property, he fails to notice and remark on the water stains on the ceilings of the upstairs rooms. In several showings, he is more than an hour late in meeting the prospective buyer. One appointment he forgets altogether. At a scheduled open house, he appears disheveled and sleepy or perhaps under the influence. In what way, if any, is Francis probably violating license law?
Choice 1: None
Choice 2: He is making false promises
Choice 3: He is dealing dishonestly
Choice 4: He is acting negligently and incompetently
Explanation: Alabama law requires a person to be trustworthy and competent to practice real estate. The law further mandates that an individual must not act negligently or incompetently in performing any of those acts which require a license

Question: Karen is selling a property that has been on the market for several months with no offers. She decides to offer an incentive to anyone who will purchase the property. She will provide a 2-year home warranty to the buyer. The home warranty will be set up and signed at the purchase closing. She doesn't want to tell the seller that she had to go to such lengths to sell the property, so she will have the buyer agree to a nondisclosure clause. Are her activities legal?

Choice 2: Yes, because she is providing the incentive prior to or at closing as required by law
Choice 3: No, because the cost of the warranty is more than what is allowed by law
Choice 4: No, because incentives must be disclosed
Explanation: In Alabama, the incentive must be given before or at closing and must be disclosed to all parties involved in the transaction, to include the seller, buyer, and lender or guaranteeing agency (FHA, VA, HUD)

Question: Why is offering a lottery as incentive to purchase a home illegal in Alabama?

Question: Sales agent Anthony sold a property for Mr. Jessup, so Mr. Jessup paid Anthony the commission as set forth in the listing agreement. Choice 1: He used his personal account to cash the check, which violated the commingling laws
Choice 2: He did not report the amount of the check to his qualifying broker
Choice 3: He did not wait for the check to clear his account before spending the money
Choice 4: He accepted the commission from someone other than his qualifying broker

Question: Shawn moved his business office to another location. He changed the address on all of his advertising, business cards, and other documents. Question: Which brokerage relationship requires written consent of all parties for the agent to represent more than one party in the same transaction? Without the written consent, the agent is in violation of the law
